image.altText: An older man with greying light hair and glasses wearing a suit and tie stands in front of a blue Reserve Bank of Australia wall

items.synopsis: Annual inflation has risen to 6.8 per cent over the year to April, in a result worse than economists had predicted. It comes after RBA boss Phillip Lowe faced a grilling at Senate estimates. Follow live.

title.children: Inflation up 6.8pc over 12 months as cost of living rises faster than economists expected

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The main reason the Consumer Price Index rose in April was because the cut in the fuel excise in April 2022 ended in October last year. So over the year fuel prices increased as the fuel excise returned to its normal level. The fuel excise for petrol, diesel, and all other fuel and petroleum based products was halved for six months on March 30 2022 as a cost of living relief measure. That saw the rates for petrol and diesel fall from 44.2 cents to 22.1 cents a litre. Here is Michelle Marquardt, head of prices statistics, at the Bureau of Statistics. “It’s important to note that a significant contributor to the increase in the annual movement in April was automotive fuel." "The halving of the fuel excise tax in April 2022, which was fully unwound in October 2022, is impacting the annual movement for April 2023." She says taking out volatile items like petrol and food means the monthly Consumer Price Index comes in at 6.5 per cent in April, lower than the 6.9 per cent recorded in March.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Petrol drives inflation rise in April

children.content: The main reason the Consumer Price Index rose in April was because the cut in the fuel excise in April 2022 ended in October last year.
So over the year fuel prices increased as the fuel excise returned to its normal level.
The fuel excise for petrol, diesel, and all other fuel and petroleum based products was halved for six months on March 30 2022 as a cost of living relief measure.
That saw the rates for petrol and diesel fall from 44.2 cents to 22.1 cents a litre.
Here is Michelle Marquardt, head of prices statistics, at the Bureau of Statistics.
“It’s important to note that a significant contributor to the increase in the annual movement in April was automotive fuel."
"The halving of the fuel excise tax in April 2022, which was fully unwound in October 2022, is impacting the annual movement for April 2023."
She says taking out volatile items like petrol and food means the monthly Consumer Price Index comes in at 6.5 per cent in April, lower than the 6.9 per cent recorded in March.

props.alt: Graph showing fuel price movements 2019 to 2023

children.content: Fuel prices
(ABC)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The higher than expected inflation figures have sent the Australian stock market further into the red with the odds of the Reserve Bank raising interest rates next week increasing. At midday, the ASX 200 index is down 1.3 per cent, compared to 0.8 per cent before the data came out. Higher petrol prices drove inflation higher in April, compared to the year before when the halving of the fuel tax excise was being unwound. The Australian dollar initially jumped to 65.38 US cents when the figures came out at 11:30am AEST, but fell 0.2 per cent to 64.93 US cents five minutes later when traders read through the ABS release. IG Markets Tony Sycamore says the chances of the RBA raising official rates next Tuesday is higher. "This is an ugly number, and despite a run of softer data earlier this month across wages, employment and retail sales, the probability that the RBA raises rates by 0.25 per cent to 4.10 per cent at its meeting next week has increased to ~25 per cent" "Heading into the number, the market was pricing a 10 per cent chance of an RBA rate hike next week."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hotter inflation data sees ASX extend falls

children.content: The higher than expected inflation figures have sent the Australian stock market further into the red with the odds of the Reserve Bank raising interest rates next week increasing.
At midday, the ASX 200 index is down 1.3 per cent, compared to 0.8 per cent before the data came out.
Higher petrol prices drove inflation higher in April, compared to the year before when the halving of the fuel tax excise was being unwound.

The Australian dollar initially jumped to 65.38 US cents when the figures came out at 11:30am AEST, but fell 0.2 per cent to 64.93 US cents five minutes later when traders read through the ABS release.
IG Markets Tony Sycamore says the chances of the RBA raising official rates next Tuesday is higher.
"This is an ugly number, and despite a run of softer data earlier this month across wages, employment and retail sales, the probability that the RBA raises rates by 0.25 per cent
to 4.10 per cent at its meeting next week has increased to ~25 per cent"
"Heading into the number, the market was pricing a 10 per cent chance of an RBA rate hike next week."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Bureau of Statistics says consumer inflation surged over the year to April despite higher interest rates. The monthly figures show that the Consumer Price Index rose 6.8 per cent from April last year. That's compared to a rise of 6.3 per cent over the year to March. The most significant price rises were housing, food and non alcoholic beverages and transport. ANZ economists had expected annual inflation to rise by 6.4 per cent.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Consumer inflation up 6.8% over year to April

children.content: The Bureau of Statistics says consumer inflation surged over the year to April despite higher interest rates.
The monthly figures show that the Consumer Price Index rose 6.8 per cent from April last year.
That's compared to a rise of 6.3 per cent over the year to March.
The most significant price rises were housing, food and non alcoholic beverages and transport.
ANZ economists had expected annual inflation to rise by 6.4 per cent.

image.altText: NIBLITT OUTSIDE HOUSE

items.synopsis: Two years after signing a $430,000 fixed price contract, boilermaker David Niblitt can no longer afford to finish the home that he and his wife had hoped they'd be living in by now.

title.children: David's half-built house is an 'absolute nightmare' and might send him bankrupt

image.altText: Two people ski through snow on Launceston street.

items.synopsis: Winter in Tasmania is not all snow-capped mountains and teeth-chattering frosts. The coldest season brings all kinds of possible weather around the island state.

title.children: Snow and fog, sure — but what other weather does winter bring to Tasmania?

image.altText: Tasmanian Liberal politician Nic Street.

items.synopsis: The minister responsible for Tasmania's community services sector — which includes mental health, disability and homelessness organisations — apologised to the peak body for last week's state budget, which he described as "inadequate".

title.children: Minister's admission over 'inadequate' budget funds for community services

image.altText: Above view of inside parliament, a large group sit on the right a much smaller group on the left.

items.synopsis: The bill still needs to be dealt with by the Senate, which is likely next month, before the federal government sets a date for the poll later this year.

title.children: Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum bill passes lower house; Nationals, some Liberals voting against

image.altText: St Johns Park aerial visualisation.

items.synopsis: A proposed new health and wellbeing precinct in Hobart's New Town will include mental health, palliative care and an eating disorder clinic. But there are concerns about the number of inpatient beds to be provided.

title.children: Eating disorder clinic among new facilities at proposed new Hobart health precinct

image.altText: man facing forward

items.synopsis: Michael Davis appeared in Sydney's Fairfield Local Court today charged with four counts of using a carriage service to threaten serious harm and to menace, harass or offend.

title.children: Sydney man who allegedly threatened Stan Grant and his family faces court

image.altText: Hawthorn Hawks signage at the clubs headquarters in Melbourne.

items.synopsis: An AFL panel has made no findings against former coaches and staff over racism allegations, but the AFL CEO says the club could still face punishment.

title.children: Hawthorn president says sanctions over its handling of racism allegations would be 'extremely disappointing'

image.altText: Selfie of 16-year-old Pasawm Lyhym.

items.synopsis: A 17-year-old boy is charged with murder over the stabbing of teenager Pasawm Lyhym in an altercation between two groups at Sunshine, in Melbourne's west, this month.

title.children: Police charge teenager with murder over Melbourne stabbing

image.altText: A woman holds an adrenaline pen and anti-inflammatory tablets in a garden.

items.synopsis: One sting from a jack jumper ant lurking in Jennie Kun's garden could be deadly. She's just started a treatment program to train her body to stop being allergic, but says it needs to be made more accessible.

title.children: Jennie loves gardening but she has to 'suit up' to protect herself against a deadly ant

image.altText: A woman with a black blazer holders a book while standing in a garden.

items.synopsis: South Korea hoped that a 69-hour working week would encourage more women to have children and solve the country's ageing population problem, but women say the real barrier is embedded in the culture.

title.children: South Korea wants women to have more babies, but their latest idea outraged millennials and Gen Z

image.altText: Antarctica hits new low sea ice extent

items.synopsis: Antarctica's sea ice is now reforming as the continent moves deeper into the austral winter, but it's currently the smallest it has ever been for this time of year on record. This blip in the Antarctic pulse is the latest in a string of record lows that is being watched carefully by scientists.

title.children: A stutter in Earth's icy heartbeat has 'gravely concerned' scientists searching for answers

image.altText: An elderly lady holds up two faded photos of a small, smiling boy

items.synopsis: It's been almost 50 years since Jimmy Taylor vanished from outside a shop in his home town. Now a new suspect and a $1 million reward have sparked hopes the mystery may be solved.

title.children: Jimmy Taylor was 12 when he vanished. Now there's a new suspect and a $1 million reward

image.altText: A man smiles and waves at the crowd.

items.synopsis: Adam Goodes tells Rio Ferdinand that he wishes he could go back in time and stop his mum from being a part of the Stolen Generation.

title.children: 'If I'm only known for football, I've failed': Goodes opens up in rare interview with soccer star

image.altText: Two men walking.

items.synopsis: Robert "Bobby" Bourke was on trial for his role in the attempted blackmail of fellow Bathurst councillor Jacqui Rudge in March 2020.

title.children: Jury finds former Bathurst mayor Bobby Bourke guilty in blackmail trial

image.altText: A man in a blazer and white shirt smiles as he's being filmed by a TV camera.

items.synopsis: Roger Cook hits the ground running, meeting with Labor's right faction today to confirm his endorsement as WA's next premier, as the opposition slams the role of the unions in anointing him.

title.children: Roger Cook set to clear final hurdles in path to becoming new WA premier, as opposition slams union influence

image.altText: A woman standing in front of a shipping container

items.synopsis: Sally Marvin lost her home to floods and has been housed in temporary accommodation since January — she still does not know when it will be safe to return home.

title.children: After six months in huts, these WA flood victims are still waiting to go home

image.altText: A beluga whale being fed fish from a boat.

items.synopsis: A marine biologist tracking Hvaldimir says the beluga whale's solitude has cause him to seek human companionship.

title.children: Alleged Russian spy whale risking danger to cure loneliness

image.altText: A man in a suit and tie smiles broadly while watching another man in a suit and tie speak.

items.synopsis: WA's incoming premier has every reason to be brimming with confidence, but he also faces the challenge of keeping a cohesive cabinet and controlling a massive cohort of backbenchers, writes state political reporter James Carmody.

title.children: Roger Cook will inherit the power — and problems — of Mark McGowan's massive majority

image.altText: A close up portrait of Victorian Liberal MP Ryan Smith.

items.synopsis: Voters in Melbourne's north-east will head to the polls for the third time in just over a year, after Liberal MP Ryan Smith — a critic of leader John Pesutto — called time on his Victorian political career.

title.children: Electoral test looms for Victorian Liberals as longtime MP resigns

image.altText: A lady in a blue puffer jacket sits as a wooden table with her arms crossed in an electrical store

items.synopsis: The Insurance Council of Australia says extreme weather events are helping to push up premiums. They are also pushing many small business owners in Queensland to the brink.

title.children: Anna's town is protected by a flood levee, but it hasn't stopped her insurance going up $13,000 this year

image.altText: A live export ship being guided into port by a tug boat.

items.synopsis: A live export ship that broke down at Darwin Port after it was loaded with about 1,800 head of cattle two weeks ago has been repaired, reloaded and departed for Indonesia.

title.children: Live export ship leaves Darwin with cattle two weeks after engine failure

image.altText: Karen man standing in front of colourful mural painted on a building wall

items.synopsis: The very first Myanmar refugee to establish a life in the Western Australian town recounts the long journey there after escaping conflict at home, then spending a decade in a Thailand camp where he and his wife raised four children.

title.children: Albany's Myanmar population started with just one refugee. Now it's home to more than 170

image.altText: A man dressed in council robes sitting down with a young girl on his lap and two older young girls looking over his shoulder

items.synopsis: While Victoria has had a horror week on the roads with 10 lives lost in four days, Laurie Whelan feels the families' pain, 21 years on from his own road tragedy.

title.children: 'It was just a normal morning': It's 21 years since Laurie's wife and two daughters died on the school run

image.altText: Sohae Satellite Launching Station is seen in a satellite image.

items.synopsis: A "space satellite" launch by North Korea has malfunctioned, sending the craft plunging into the sea, and prompting emergency alerts and brief evacuation warnings in parts of South Korea and Japan.

title.children: North Korean 'space satellite' plunges into sea, prompting brief alerts in South Korea and Japan

items.synopsis: Video shows a fighter jet passing in front of the US plane's nose and the cockpit of the RC-135 shaking in the turbulence.

title.children: Chinese jet carried out 'aggressive' manoeuvre near US military plane, Washington says

image.altText: A worker abseils against a building to inspect drone damage.

items.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin says the biggest-ever drone strike on Moscow targeted civilians, accusing Ukraine of an attack that would warrant a "severe" response.

title.children: Russia warns Ukraine of harsh response after 'terrorist' drone strike on Moscow

image.altText: Close up of blonde haired woman in dressed in black.

items.synopsis: The 39-year-old startup founder could spend more than 11 years inside a prison camp in Texas for defrauding investors in a hoax that became a parable about greed and hubris in Silicon Valley.

title.children: Elizabeth Holmes begins 11-year sentence for Theranos blood-testing hoax

image.altText: A composite of three images

items.synopsis: With almost half of Australians having a parent born overseas, multicultural Australians' vote in the Voice referendum could prove significant. It's a cohort both the Yes and No campaigns are trying to court with community forums.

title.children: 'We can no longer be ignored': Why the Yes and No campaigns are courting multicultural votes ahead of the Voice referendum

image.altText: The plane which was carrying the four children was discovered in thick jungle.

items.synopsis: The discovery of a rudimentary shelter, some half-eaten fruit and a fresh footprint leads authorities to say they are "very close" to finding the children, who they believe have roamed the jungle since a plane crash.

title.children: Rescuers 'very close' to finding lost kids after finding footprint in Colombian Amazon

image.altText: A man and woman sit a bench, looking at paper bills, with a calculator and laptop next to them

items.synopsis: Economists are divided on how well households will weather the storm of rent rises, soaring home loan rates and rising prices, just as Australians are divided in how much financial pressure they're under.

title.children: 'I don't think that's sustainable for the economy': How the RBA might drag Australia into recession

image.altText: a group of male students wearing backpacks walk through a uni campus away from the camera. their faces can't be seen

items.synopsis: For the past decade, student debts have increased by about 2 per cent a year on average, but tomorrow they will rise by a massive 7.1 per cent. The consequences of increased debt will affect graduates for decades.

title.children: Indexation of student debts to have lifelong impacts on Australians' borrowing capacity

image.altText: Jesse Southwell looks to pass the football

items.synopsis: Ahead of her New South Wales debut, Jesse Southwell is a product of the past and a vision of the future when it comes to State of Origin football.

title.children: This women's rugby league prodigy is ready to make her mark on State of Origin football
